docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Gray Weinblatt, a daughter of Barbara S. Weinblatt and Dr. Michael E. Weinblatt of Waban, Mass., was married on Martha’s Vineyard yesterday to Jason Christopher Chapman, the son of Dr. Holly J. Chapman and Cliff Chapman of Eagle River, Alaska. The Rev. Dr. Jerry Fritz, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Federated Church in Edgartown, Mass.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Tasini's campaign says it has collected the signatures the candidate needs to enter the Democratic primary against Hillary Rodham Clinton. This afternoon, his campaign announced that he plans to appear at the Board of Elections next week to deliver signed ballot-access petitions.
docs.abstract: Jonathan Tasini petitioning for signatures in Union Square on June 23. docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Lois Ashkin, a daughter of Fran Ashkin and Dr. Jeffrey Ashkin of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to Andrew David Beckman, a son of Susan Beckman and Michael Beckman, both of New York. Rabbi Howard Buechler officiated at the Ritz-Carlton at Battery Park in New York. Mrs. Beckman, 28, is a fourth-grade teacher at Public School 2 in Lawrence, N.Y. She graduated from the University of Michigan and received a master's degree in education from Hunter College. Her father is a gastroenterologist at Western Suffolk Gastroenterology Associates, a group practice, and is the chief of gastroenterology at Southside Hospital, both in Bay Shore, N.Y.

docs.lead_paragraph: Campaign money is like quicksilver -- it will squirt through any opening you give it. No one knows that better than the troglodytes on the Federal Election Commission who would love to poke all sorts of crippling loopholes in the nation's brand new campaign finance law. Unfortunately, some of the Senate Democrats who supported reform are now wavering over whether to let the commission get away with this high-handed maneuver. Among the tremulous lawmakers is Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has not decided whether to join in overturning the commission's most recent regulations. Mrs. Clinton voted for the McCain-Feingold ''soft money'' ban and notes that she disavowed soft money in her Senate campaign in 2000. But her record will be seriously tarnished if she does not block the election commission's attempt to use the rule-making process to eviscerate the law. At issue are a set of regulations that delineate the law's ban on raising, directing or receiving unlimited funds from corporations, unions and rich donors for state parties. A four-vote majority on the commission adopted the narrowest possible definition of what was banned, opening the possibility that presidents, senators or other officeholders could, with a wink and a nod, suggest that donors make such contributions. The regulation is a license for a return to the egregious fund-raising practices that Democrats and Republicans have employed in recent years.
docs.abstract: Editorial scores 'troglodytes' on Federal Election Commission who would like to poke all sorts of crippling loopholes in nation's brand new campaign finance law; criticizes Sen Hillary Clinton for not yet joining Sen Russell Feingold and others who would overturn commission's new regulations, telling her that what is needed are not more creative loopholes but airtight ban

docs.lead_paragraph: Gotham reporters have missed a few big stories over the years. They still haven't figured out, for instance, that Bruce Wayne is Batman. Yet in every story about Hillary Clinton running for the Senate here, it is suggested that she might be scared off by a howling New York press pack that relishes asking the unaskable.
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd column surveys New York journalists on the kinds of questions they would put to Hillary Rodham Clinton if she should choose to run for Senate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton will be in New Jersey on Sunday to urge supporters not to be complacent about the outcome of the Nov. 5 election and to campaign for Representative Robert G. Torricelli. The First Lady will appear at the Pavilion at Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, said Jo Astrid-Glading, a campaign spokeswoman.
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton will appear at Pavilion at Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, NJ, on Sunday, Nov 3, to urge big voter turnout (S) (New Jersey Daily Briefing)
